{{Maginot Line Infobox |localisation=[[File:otterbiel carte.jpg|300px]] |type=PO |year=1933 |sector=[[Fortified Sector of Rohrbach]] |sub-sector=Sub-Sector of Bitche |number=O 400, ''Ouvrage B'' |regiment=37th Fortress Infantry Regiment (RIF) |blocks=5 |entrance= |strength=7 officers, 98 men |picture= |caption= }}
'''Ouvrage Otterbiel''' forms part of the [[Maginot Line]] in the Fortified Sector of Rohrbach, Sub-sector of Bitche, and is located on the ''Camp de Bitche'' of the [[French Army]]. It is located between ''gros ouvrage'' [[Ouvrage Schiesseck|Schiesseck]] and ''petit ouvrage'' [[Ouvrage Grand Hohekirkel|Grand Hohekirkel]]. Part of the [[Fortified Sector of Rohrbach]], the ''petit ouvrage'' comprises four combat blocks and an entry block. Due to budget restrictions, a planned flanking infantry block was never constructed. Otterbiel saw no significant action in the [[Battle of France]], and limited action during the 1944/45 [[Lorraine Campaign]]. It was renovated for use during the [[Cold War]]. Otterbiel is used for ammunition storage by the French Army.
== Design and construction == The site was surveyed by Commission d'Organisation des Régions Fortifiées (CORF), the Maginot Line's design and construction agency, and was approved for construction in August 1931. The ''petit ouvrage''{{#tag:ref|English-language sources use the French term ''ouvrage'' as the preferred term for the Maginot positions, in preference to "fort", a term usually reserved for older fortifications with passive defenses in the form of walls and ditches.<ref name="kaufmann1">Kaufmann 2006, p. 13</ref> The literal translation of ''ouvrage'' in the sense of a fortification in English is "work." A ''gros ouvrage'' is a large fortification with a significant artillery component, while a ''petit ouvrage'' is smaller, with lighter arms.<ref>Kaufmann 2006, p. 20</ref>|group="nb"}} was initially planned as a ''gros ouvrage'' with additional blocks for an 81mm mortar turret and two 75mm gun casemates, as well as a separate personnel entry.<ref name="hetou3-1">Mary, Tome 3, p. 128</ref>
== Description == Otterbiel is unusual for having an artillery block in a ''petit ouvrage'', a vestige of its original intention as a ''gros ouvrage''. It also possesses three infantry blocks and a single entry block. *'''Block 1''': Infantry block with one retractable twin machine gun turret and one [[GFM cloche|automatic rifle cloche (GFM)]]. Access forbidden.<ref name="fortiffbe1">{{cite web|url=http://www.fortiff.be/maginot/index.php?p=4255|title=Otterbiel (go du) Bloc 1|last=Puelinckx|first=Jean|year=2010|work=Index de la Ligne Maginot|publisher=fortiff.be|language=French|accessdate=8 June 2010|display-authors=etal}}</ref> *'''Block 2''': Infantry block with two GFM cloches, one [[LG cloche|grenade launcher cloche (LG)]], one [[JM cloche|twin machine gun cloche (JM)]], one twin machine gun embrasure and one machine gun (JM)/[[AC 47 anti-tank gun|47mm anti-tank gun]] embrasure (JM/AC47). Access forbidden.<ref name="fortiffbe2">{{cite web|url=http://www.fortiff.be/maginot/index.php?p=4256|title=Otterbiel (go du) Bloc 2|last=Puelinckx|first=Jean|year=2010|work=Index de la Ligne Maginot|publisher=fortiff.be|language=French|accessdate=8 June 2010|display-authors=etal}}</ref> *'''Block 3''': Infantry block with two GFM cloches, one JM cloche, one 81mm mortar turret, one twin machine gun embrasure and one JM/AC47 embrasure. Access forbidden.<ref name="fortiffbe3">{{cite web|url=http://www.fortiff.be/maginot/index.php?p=4257|title=Otterbiel (go du) Bloc 3|last=Puelinckx|first=Jean|year=2010|work=Index de la Ligne Maginot|publisher=fortiff.be|language=French|accessdate=8 June 2010|display-authors=etal}}</ref> *'''Block 4''': Infantry block with two GFM cloches and one [[VDP cloche|observation cloche (VDP)]]. Access forbidden.<ref name="fortiffbe4">{{cite web|url=http://www.fortiff.be/maginot/index.php?p=4258|title=Otterbiel (go du) Bloc 4|last=Puelinckx|first=Jean|year=2010|work=Index de la Ligne Maginot|publisher=fortiff.be|language=French|accessdate=8 June 2010|display-authors=etal}}</ref> *'''Entry block:''' The entry provides for personnel and [[ammunition]] on one unit, with munitions arriving by truck. It is protected by two GFM cloches and a machine gun/[[AC 47 anti-tank gun|47mm anti-tank gun]] (JM/AC47) embrasure, which was never provided due to a lack of funding; only a machine gun was provided.<ref name="fortiffbe1a">{{cite web|url=http://www.fortiff.be/maginot/index.php?p=4263|title=Otterbiel (go du) Entrée|last=Puelinckx|first=Jean|year=2010|work=Index de la Ligne Maginot|publisher=fortiff.be|language=French|accessdate=8 June 2010|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
=== Casemates and shelters === A series of detached [[casemate]]s and infantry shelters are in the vicinity of Otterbiel, including * '''Casemate du Champ d'Aviation Ouest''': Single block with one JM/AC37 embrasure, one twin machine gun embrasure and a GFM cloche. * '''Casemate du Champ d'Aviation Est''': Single block with one JM/AC47 embrasure, one twin machine gun embrasure and a GFM cloche. * '''Abri du Kindelberg''': Subsurface ''abri-caverne''{{#tag:ref|An ''abri'' is an infantry shelter, sometimes underground or under earth cover. An ''abri'' in the main Maginot Line often closely resembles a casemate, but is more lightly armed and can hold more occupants.<ref>Kaufmann 2006, p. 14</ref>|group="nb"}} with two GFM cloches * '''Casemate de Rochat Ouest''': Single block with one JM/AC37 embrasure, one twin machine gun embrasure and a GFM cloche. * '''Casemate de Rochat Est''': Single block with one JM/AC37 embrasure, one twin machine gun embrasure and a GFM cloche. * '''Casemate du Petit-Hohékirkel''': Single block with one JM/AC37 embrasure, one twin machine gun embrasure and a GFM cloche. * '''Casemate du Grand-Hohékirkel Ouest''': Single block with one JM/AC37 embrasure, one twin machine gun embrasure and a GFM cloche. * '''Casemate du Grand-Hohékirkel Est''': Single block with one JM/AC37 embrasure, one twin machine gun embrasure and a GFM cloche. * '''Abri du Camp''': Surface ''abri'' with two GFM cloches.<ref name="hetou3-1"/>
== Manning == In 1939 the garrison comprised 98 men and 7 officers of the 37th Fortress Infantry Regiment under the command of Captain Le Guanec.<ref name="hetou3-1"/> The units were under the umbrella of the 5th Army<ref>Mary, Tome 3, p. 123</ref> The Casernement de Bitche provided peacetime above-ground barracks and support services to Otterbiel and other positions in the area.<ref>Mary, Tome 3, p. 117</ref><ref name="dkpl0">{{cite web|url=http://www.darkplaces.org/Frankreich/WW2/Ligne_Maginot/SF_de_Rohrbach/SF_de_Rohrbach.html|title=Festungsabschnitt Rohrbach |last=Wahl|first=J.B.|publisher=darkplaces.org|language=German|accessdate=8 June 2010}}</ref>
== History == :''See [[Fortified Sector of Rohrbach]] for a broader discussion of the Rohrbach sector of the Maginot Line.'' === 1940 === Otterbiel saw relatively little action in 1940 compared to its neighbors, and surrendered to the Germans with the rest of the Bitche fortifications on 30 June 1940.<ref>Mary, Tome 3, pp. 233, 237</ref>
=== 1944 and 1945 === At the end of November 1944 the [[United States Army Europe|U.S. Seventh Army]] under General [[Alexander Patch]] had reached the Vosges region. Otterbiel was occupied by elements of the German 25th Panzer Grenadier Division.<ref name="usaww2-1">{{cite web|last=Clarke|first=Jeremy|title=On to the Siegfried Line|url=http://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/USA/USA-E-Riviera/USA-E-Riviera-26.html|work=The U.S. Army in World War II|publisher=|accessdate=9 June 2010|pages=471–475}}</ref> Otterbiel was to be the next position to be attacked by the [[100th Infantry Division (United States)|U.S. 100th Infantry Division]], but the planned operation was disrupted by the [[Battle of the Bulge]]. The Seventh Army withdrew to cover areas vacated by the [[United States Army Central|U.S. Third Army]], which moved to confront the German offensive.<ref name="milhisto1">{{cite web|last=Dickerson|first=Bryan J.|title=The US Army vs. the Maginot Line|url=http://www.militaryhistoryonline.com/wwii/articles/maginotline.aspx|publisher=Military History Online|accessdate=8 June 2010}}</ref>
The 100th returned in March 1945 attacked the area on a broad front. Otterbiel was lightly defended, and the Americans, backed up by heavy artillery, were able to capture Otterbiel and the ''Ensemble de Bitche'' with few casualties.<ref name="milhisto1"/>
=== Cold War === Following World War II, interest revived in the use of the Maginot Line to defend against a possible Soviet advance through southern Germany. Funds were allocated for restoration of the ''gros ouvrages'', but work was limited to restoration of systems and improvements to existing armament, with work completed by 1953. By 1953, Otterbiel had been designated part of the ''Mòle de Bitche'', a strongpoint in the northeastern defenses against Soviet attack.<ref name="hetou5-1">Mary Tome 5, p. 161</ref> By the late 1950s interest in fixed fortifications was waning after France developed a nuclear deterrent. The money needed to maintain and upgrade the fortifications was diverted for the nuclear programs. Otterbiel was not manned or maintained after the early 1970s<ref>Mary, Tome 5, p. 173</ref>
== Present condition == Otterbiel is on military land and is not accessible to the public. It is reportedly used for ammunition storage.<ref name="donnell1">{{cite web|last=Donnell|first=Clayton|title=Off the Beaten Path|url=http://webspace.webring.com/people/gb/bunkernut/beaten.html}}</ref>
